author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Won’t Decide Nvidia Securities Fraud Case After All
description: In an unsigned order, the justices dismissed the case against the tech giant as “improvidently granted,” meaning they had concluded that it had been a mistake to take it up.
content: The Supreme Court, which heard arguments last month about whether to allow a lawsuit accusing Nvidia of misrepresenting its reliance on the cryptocurrency mining industry, announced on Wednesday that it would not decide the case after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Passes Defense Bill Denying Transgender Health Coverage for Minors
description: The $895 billion measure was approved over the opposition of most Democrats, who rejected a provision inserted by Republicans to deny the coverage to the minor children of military personnel.
content: A divided House on Wednesday passed a defense policy bill that would direct $895 billion to the Pentagon and other military operations, moving over the opposition of Democrats who objected to a provision denying coverage for transgender health care for the children of service members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Besonen
title: A Local’s Guide to Celebrating the Holidays in New York
description: Facing crushing throngs and high prices can be as off-putting as a rock-hard bagel. Here’s how New Yorkers enjoy their hometown’s seasonal traditions without much challenge to their patience or pocketbook.
content: In December, New Yorkers like to indulge in frothy hot chocolate and other traditional Yuletide treats as much as the city’s holiday visitors do, but facing crushing throngs and high prices, particularly at home, can be as off-putting as a rock-hard bagel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: For Rastafarians, Marijuana Is Sacred. Should the Law Account for That?
description: Members of the religious group would like to see New York’s cannabis legalization law revised to include accommodations for those who use the drug in worship.
content: For Rastafarians like Richard Chung, a leather craftsman with a bundle of salt-and-pepper dreadlocks, marijuana has long been both sacred and a livelihood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Nico Grant
title: Google Unveils A.I. Agent That Can Use Websites on Its Own
description: The experimental tool can browse spreadsheets, shopping sites and other services, before taking action on behalf of the computer user.
content: Today, chatbots can answer questions, write poems and generate images. In the future, they could also autonomously perform tasks like online shopping and work with tools like spreadsheets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can the U.S. Climb Out of Its ‘Unprecedented’ Housing Crisis?
description: The 2024 housing market was the slowest in decades. Next year’s might not be much better. It may come down to how many new homes can be built.
content: A young family in Grand Rapids, Mich., has been looking for a larger house for three years, losing countless bidding wars. In Portland, Maine, a 29-year-old data analyst has been anxious to get out of their rental for a year, but hasn’t found a home to buy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.35 Million Homes in New York, Nevada and Connecticut
description: A home from 1900 in Woodstock, a midcentury modern house in Las Vegas and a converted barn in Chester.
content: This three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath house, which also has a guesthouse with a full bathroom, was part of the Byrdcliffe Arts Colony, founded in the early 20th century, and host to painters, novelists and performers over decades. Some original character has been restored, including dark wood siding and turquoise window trim. Mechanical and HVAC systems, gutters and the roof are new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: Opioids Ravaged a Kentucky Town. Then Rehab Became Its Business.
description: In Louisa, an unbearable social crisis has become the main source of economic opportunity.
content: Louisa, Ky., is a small town of about 2,600 on the border of West Virginia with a single pair of railroad tracks running through it. If you follow these tracks south, against the flow of the Big Sandy River, you’ll go between the public library and the Main Street Park and over Lick Creek, one of the manifold creeks that web eastern Kentucky like capillaries. Follow Lick Creek past a baseball diamond and a pawnshop and you’ll arrive behind an ordinary gray mobile home in a small lot of grass where Ingrid Jackson was living in the fall of 2023. The days were still long and the afternoon sun settled gently on nearby mountains, turning leaves a lambent red. Reedy gospel music played from inside the trailer, announcing Jackson’s presence as she opened the door. Her hair, normally figured in light brown curls, was packed into a shower cap. She smiled from the entryway. It was a smile difficult not to smile back at.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Maria Cramer
title: Police Say Suspect’s Notebook Described Rationale for C.E.O. Killing
description: “It’s targeted, precise and doesn’t risk innocents,” said a sentence in a spiral notebook belonging to the man charged with murdering Brian Thompson.
content: Luigi Mangione, who has been charged with killing the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare outside a company investors’ day in Manhattan, was arrested with a notebook that detailed plans for the shooting, according to two law enforcement officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Diamond
title: A Danish Christmas Tradition That Comes From the Heart
description: In the land of hygge, handmade paper decorations have long brought holiday cheer — and a chance to share the simple joys of crafting.
content: Liselotte Elsborg can’t remember when she learned to make the paper decorations that are ubiquitous in her native Denmark during Christmas time. “In my mind, I have always been able to do these things,” she said. She’s been expertly interlacing the strands of Christmas hearts, or julehjerter (YOU-luh-YAIR-duh), for so many decades, she said, that it “is probably part of my DNA.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zaina Erhaim
title: Al-Assad Is Gone, and One Idea Fills My Brain

content: What is life without al-Assad?
source.name: The New York Times

description: We explain the scale of recent immigration to America.

source.name: The New York Times

title: Who Is Mohammed al-Bashir, Syria’s Caretaker Prime Minister?
description: Mr. al-Bashir previously headed a rebel-led administration in northwestern Syria. He has been tasked with running the country’s interim government until March.
content: Mohammed al-Bashir is an electrical engineering graduate who had been administering a sliver of rebel-held territory in northwestern Syria before he was tasked this week with heading Syria’s interim government, as the country faces many grave challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hunt Continues for U.S. Journalist Who Disappeared in Syria
description: The U.S. has identified prisons of interest as it searches for clues about Austin Tice, who was abducted in 2012 and whose fate remains unknown.
content: The United States has identified a handful of prisons in Syria that might provide clues to the fate of Austin Tice, an American journalist who was abducted in 2012 and believed held by the Syrian government.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Syria’s New Leaders Balance Huge Struggles Amid Disorder
description: The rebels who seized control called for foreign help in prosecuting atrocities, while trying to restore order in a fractured country.
content: The rebels who seized control of Syria confronted the challenge on Wednesday of striking a balance between obtaining justice for the victims of atrocities committed under the ousted Assad regime and preventing the newly liberated country from descending into unchecked vengeance.

content: President-elect Donald J. Trump has said little about the specifics of how he would carry out the promised largest deportation effort in American history. But immigration experts say it would be nearly impossible to execute without some critical assistance, particularly from jails and prisons.

title: Blast in Afghanistan Kills a Taliban Leader, Khalil Haqqani

content: An explosion in Afghanistan’s capital on Wednesday killed a Taliban official who was a member of one of the country’s most powerful political families, government officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Genre Movies of 2024

content: It’s been an odd year for science fiction. One of the best such narratives was the Broadway musical “Maybe Happy Ending,” set in 2064 Seoul and in which two obsolete robots fall in love. Streaming series gave us an astounding range of stories and aesthetics, from “Sugar” to “Fallout” to “Dune: Prophecy.”

content: Demand for electricity is rising so quickly in the United States that even Exxon Mobil, the country’s largest oil and gas company, is planning to get into the power business.

title: U.S. Strategy on Syria Risks ISIS Resurgence, Kurdish General Warns

content: The commander of Syria’s largest Kurdish militia has accused the United States of abandoning its Kurdish allies in Syria, key partners in America’s fight against the Islamic State, and warned of a resurgence by the Islamic State amid political uncertainty in Syria.

content: The residence halls had lost power, and cell service was not working. Embers had sparked tiny flare-ups on the school grounds, setting palm trees ablaze. Helicopters were descending to extract water from a campus pond.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What the Suspect in the C.E.O.’s Killing Has Revealed About Himself
description: The man arrested in Brian Thompson’s murder “views himself as a hero of sorts,” the police have said.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Bans Puberty Blockers for Teens Indefinitely
description: A freeze placed this year on their use to treat gender dysphoria will remain in place for young people under 18, except in clinical trials, Britain’s government said.
content: Britain is to ban indefinitely the use of puberty blockers for young people under 18 with gender dysphoria, except in clinical trials, the government said on Wednesday, making permanent a set of temporary restrictions put in place earlier this year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inflation Ticks Up, but Details Are Encouraging for the Fed
description: Inflation sped up last month, but the details suggested cooling ahead. Next week, the Fed will make its final rate decision for 2024.
content: Fresh inflation data released on Wednesday made clear that the Federal Reserve’s fight against rapid price increases was not over. Still, the details of the report probably gave central bank officials enough confidence to cut interest rates at their meeting next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Berehulak and Christina Goldbaum
title: A Search in Syria for the Disappeared
description: Syrians raced to newly emptied prisons to reunite with loved ones snatched away by the brutal regime of Bashar al-Assad, but their quest sometimes took them to the morgue.
content: For over a decade, tens of thousands of people living in Syria would disappear without explanation. They were picked up off the street. Plucked from university classes. Yanked out of stores as they bought groceries, and from taxis on their way home from work.

title: Traveling to the U.K. Soon? You Might Need to Apply and Pay a Fee First.
description: As of Jan. 8, an electronic travel authorization will be required for visitors from dozens of visa-exempt countries, including the United States and Canada.
content: Travelers from the United States, Canada and dozens of other countries who do not require visas to enter the United Kingdom will soon need to apply for digital authorization in order to visit or transit through the country.

title: Preet Bharara to Investigate State Police Slowdown in New Jersey

content: New Jersey’s attorney general announced on Wednesday that he had enlisted Preet Bharara, a former Manhattan federal prosecutor, to lead a criminal investigation into a protracted slowdown in traffic enforcement by State Police troopers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher R. Weingarten
title: ‘The Texas Chain Saw Massacre’ Score, a Noisy Gem, Will Arrive at Last
description: Fifty-one years after the smash horror movie, its groundbreaking and unconventional music — long a “holy grail” — will arrive on vinyl.
content: In 1996, years before helping to found the experimental rock institution Animal Collective, David Portner and Brian Weitz were Baltimore high school pals who diligently hunted for the soundtrack album that perfectly meshed their love of the unorthodox sound worlds of musique concrète and the thrills of horror movies: “The Texas Chain Saw Massacre.” “It wasn’t really till years later that I found out that it had never been released,” Portner said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Allows Biden Plan to Address Toxic Coal Ash
description: The court’s order was provisional, rejecting a request from a Kentucky electric utility to block the plan while an appeals court considers its challenge.
content: The Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected a request from an electric utility in Kentucky to block an Environmental Protection Agency effort to address the health risks presented by coal ash, a toxic substance created by burning coal to produce electricity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Far-Right Militias Seek Role in Trump Deportation Plan
description: The incoming administration said it would not rely on outside groups to carry out its plan to deport millions of immigrants, but militias have a long record of inserting themselves into patrolling the border.
content: A few days after the election, William Teer, who runs the Texas Three Percenters, a local far-right militia group, wrote to President-elect Donald J. Trump with an offer: His organization could help Mr. Trump carry out his plan to deport millions of people who are in the United States illegally.

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Reed Abelson
title: Bipartisan Lawmakers Seek to Break Up Giant Health Care Conglomerates
description: New legislation would force UnitedHealth Group, CVS Health and Cigna to each sell their pharmacies within three years.
content: Members of Congress are pushing legislation that threatens to break up some of the nation’s biggest health care conglomerates, including UnitedHealth Group and CVS Health, by forcing them to sell off their retail or mail-order pharmacies.

author: By Vivian Wang
title: How a Feminist Comedy Came to Rule China’s Box Office
description: “Her Story” touches on sensitive topics in China, like censorship and gender inequality. But its humorous, nonconfrontational approach may have helped it pass censors.
content: The movie calls out stigmas against female sexuality and stereotypes about single mothers. It name-drops feminist scholars, features a woman recalling domestic violence and laments Chinese censorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christiaan Triebert and Riley Mellen
title: Russian Military and Commercial Activity Appears Halted at Key Syrian Port
description: Satellite images from last week and this week show that naval vessels docked at the port city of Tartus have left. According to marine tracking data, no cargo ships have entered or left Tartus since Monday.
content: Satellite imagery and ship tracking data reviewed by The New York Times show that Russian naval and commercial activity in the key Syrian port of Tartus — which has played a critical role in Moscow’s projection of military power in the region — has ceased since Bashar al-Assad’s government fell on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Georgia Man Charged With 1985 Murders of Couple in Church
description: Erik Sparre was arrested earlier this week, more than two decades after Dennis Perry was wrongly sent to prison for the crime.
content: Nearly 40 years after Harold and Thelma Swain were shot to death in a small church in Camden County, Ga., and after a man was wrongly sent to prison for two decades over the crime, the authorities arrested another man who they believe murdered the Swains.

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: So Much Losing

title: Who Set the Stage for al-Assad’s Ouster? There Are Different Answers in the U.S. and Israel.
description: President Biden says he weakened Russia, Iran and Hezbollah, laying the groundwork for Bashar al-Assad’s ouster. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says the Syrian leader would still be in power had he listened to American advice.
content: Bashar al-Assad had barely settled into his new quarters in Russia before the argument broke out over who can take the credit for ousting him, ending 53 years and two generations of brutal family rule over Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Men in Caring Jobs Will Make Society More Equal
description: Less stigma against male caregivers is all to the good.
content: In her prescient 2012 book, “The End of Men,” my friend Hanna Rosin described a modern American dynamic between archetypes that she called “Plastic Woman” and “Cardboard Man.” These comic book characters represented American women who made miraculous social progress in the 20th century and American men who stalled out. That’s because women in the past 60 years or so have been able to be infinitely flexible and responsive to structural economic changes and men remained rigid planks. This hasn’t just caused a shift in the job market; it’s caused a shift in the marriage market, too. If men aren’t breadwinners and they’re not caregivers, either, what are they for?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Macy’s Details Multimillion-Dollar Accounting Error in Downbeat Report
description: Analysts see much bigger challenges for the retailer than lax accounting.
content: With just two weeks until Christmas, Macy’s has been operating under a cloud.

title: Objectifying the Accused
description: What happens when violent crimes are overshadowed by appearances?
content: From the moment the world saw the smiling, unmasked face of the young man in the New York City hostel, memes began spreading about his looks. In the days since, after Luigi Mangione was identified and charged in the murder of the UnitedHealthcare chief executive Brian Thompson, it has been impossible to escape his photo. Or photos. They are proliferating.

content: Since Sunday, when it became clear that Syria was undergoing a historic change of regime, Israel has waged a sweeping aerial campaign. author: By Gia Kourlas, Brian Seibert and Roslyn Sulcas
title: Best Dance Performances of 2024
description: Once-in-a-generation ballerinas, topical works that transcended politics and a voguing “Cats” were highlights of the year.
content: If this year has shown me anything, it’s that I am pulled toward dance that is raw and cathartic, brave and complex. There might be beauty, but that’s not the draw — even with a dancer as astonishing as Mira Nadon of New York City Ballet. Her willingness to go for it is what matters, her fearlessness. As is the depth of feeling of Chloe Misseldine of American Ballet Theater. Twyla Tharp’s blend of the soulful interior with the virtuosic exterior. Ralph Lemon’s range and rage. Bill T. Jones’s bravery in exposing his vulnerability. And, particularly now, the imagination and commitment of a new generation. It’s dance that takes itself seriously.

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: With His Usual Flair, John Galliano Exits Maison Margiela
description: The star designer, who has often courted controversy, rebuilt his reputation at the Parisian fashion house. After 10 years, he said goodbye with an Instagram post.
content: The year couldn’t end without another industry-rattling departure in the fashion world. On Wednesday, John Galliano, one of the last consensus megastar designers, stepped down from his post as artistic director of Maison Margiela.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louis Lucero II
title: Maria Callas: A Visual Dictionary
description: The things that made Callas Callas.
content: Nearly half a century after her quiet death in a Paris apartment, Maria Callas continues to exert a hold on our imagination. Her interpretations of the canon are impossible to escape; her legend has — so far — proved impossible to eclipse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser, Patricia Mazzei and Debra Kamin
title: Prominent Real Estate Agents and Brothers Charged With Sex Trafficking
description: Oren and Tal Alexander, once stars of the real estate industry, had a precipitous fall after women filed lawsuits accusing them of sexual assault. Their brother Alon was also charged.
content: Two star luxury real estate brokers and their brother are accused of using their wealth and status to lure, drug and then sexually assault and rape dozens of women, according to a federal indictment made public on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Sarah Kliff
title: Reaction to C.E.O. Killing Exposes Frustrations With Health System
description: In some quarters, the suspect in Brian Thompson’s murder is being defended and even applauded by Americans who share his outrage over the insurance industry.
content: The killing of the UnitedHealthcare chief executive Brian Thompson has mesmerized a deeply polarized nation that shares a collective frustration over dealings with health insurance companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Kimmelman, Carlos Prieto, Jessica Cheung, Michael Benoist, Dan Powell, Diane Wong, Marion Lozano, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: Notre-Dame Rises From the Ashes
description: The Paris cathedral has reopened, five years after a devastating fire. The Times’s chief architecture critic tells its story.
content: On Sunday, after a fire that many feared would destroy it, and a swift renovation that defied all predictions, the Cathedral of Notre-Dame reopened to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Vora
title: Serena Williams Is Competing on a New Court: Investment
description: “I’ve learned to trust my instincts in any business venture or brand I’m championing,” the retired tennis star said in an interview at the DealBook Summit.
content: Serena Williams may have retired in 2022 from a record breaking career in professional tennis that catapulted her to global fame, but her post-tournament life keeps her just as professionally engaged, albeit in a different realm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Rocky Colavito, All-Star Slugger for Cleveland, Dies at 91
description: After he was traded in one of the most infamous deals in Cleveland’s history, the team floundered and “the curse of Rocky Colavito” was born.
content: Rocky Colavito, who was one of baseball’s leading sluggers in his time and a huge fan favorite playing the outfield for the Cleveland Indians, only to be traded away in 1960 in the most infamous deal in the club’s history, died on Tuesday at his home in Bernville, Pa. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Are Those Drones Over New Jersey? Despite Sightings, U.S. Is Skeptical.
description: Drones have been reported in at least 10 counties of the state. But a White House spokesman suggested many of them were actually manned aircraft.
content: Dozens of reported drone sightings in the skies above New Jersey have alarmed lawmakers and local officials and left them searching for answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: Sticky Toffee Pudding Is the Best Low-Stress Holiday Dessert
description: Time is precious. Let this treat do some of the work.
content: Remaining festive over the festive season can require a game plan. Contrary to what rom-coms might suggest, making the good times roll is not always a lark. The expectations of kids to be surprised, the traditions of extended family and their need to be delighted, the pressures of the season more generally: Accommodating all these can be a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: A Friend Saw My Daughter-in-Law Flirting With Another Man. What Should I Do?
description: A mother-in-law is unsure whether to say something to her son (or his wife) after hearing through the grapevine about an upsetting scene at a hotel bar.
content: A friend of mine saw my daughter-in-law in a hotel bar with a man who is not my son. As my friend reported it, my daughter-in-law was dressed to the nines, draped all over the man and feeding him with her fingers. My friend walked over to her and asked, “Where are your husband and the kids?” My daughter-in-law answered calmly, and my friend walked away. This information is making me quite angry and sad. Do I tell my son about it, ask my daughter-in-law or keep it to myself?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reflections on Motherhood, Careers and Identity
description: Readers respond to an essay by Daniela J. Lamas. Also: Andy Griffith’s Mayberry today; Donald Trump’s loyalty test; never an exile; choosing charities.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Amid Rumors of a Breakup, Kimberly Guilfoyle Is Donald Trump’s Choice for Ambassador to Greece
description: The announcement came as Donald Trump Jr. has been seen with the socialite Bettina Anderson in Florida.
content: Follow the latest updates on President-elect Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: $765 Million Contract
description: Superstar slugger Juan Soto agreed to a $765 million deal, the biggest in pro sports history. Is he — or anybody — worth it?
content: After helping to lead the New York Yankees to the World Series last year, 26-year-old slugger Juan Soto turned down his team’s offer in order to accept a $765 million, 15-year deal with their crosstown rivals, the Mets. It is the largest contract in professional sports history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Albert Sun
title: Recent Immigration Surge Has Been Largest in U.S. History
description: Under President Biden, more than two million immigrants per year have entered, government data shows.
content: The immigration surge of the past few years has been the largest in U.S. history, surpassing the great immigration boom of the late 1800s and early 1900s, according to a New York Times analysis of government data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: A Political Reckoning Will Come for Trump, Too
description: His cabinet picks show that the Republicans are hollowed out, too.
content: In our candidate-centric political system, every president is a singular figure in his own way, whose appeal to the public is at least a little distinct from that of his party. But presidents still have a relationship to that party, and their choice of cabinet members and other high-level officials can tell any close observer a good deal about the nature of that relationship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Zann
title: From the DealBook Summit: Influential People Share Their Insights
description: Industry leaders attending the conference were asked about artificial intelligence, the economy, international relations and more.
content: At last week’s DealBook Summit in New York City, leaders in business, tech, media, law and other disciplines were invited by The New York Times to lead conversations about pressing issues in their fields. Ahead of the summit, The Times sent questions to each of the Groundbreakers. Their answers have been edited and condensed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona Yacoubian
title: Al-Assad’s Fall Has Changed the Future of the Middle East
description: As a new reality in Syria sets in, a reordering of regional power dynamics is already taking shape.
content: The collapse of the regime of Bashar al-Assad not only upends decades of Assad family rule in Syria, it also promises to realign power across the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Trump’s Admiration for Royals Could Make Them a Potent Diplomatic Tool
description: A meeting between President-elect Donald J. Trump and Prince William showed Britain’s hope that the Windsors could help safeguard relations with Washington.
content: When President Donald J. Trump visited Britain in 2019, British officials arranged for him to have afternoon tea with Charles, then the Prince of Wales, at his London residence, Clarence House. The thinking among British diplomats was that the 70-something heir to the throne would be a good partner for the 70-something heir to a real estate fortune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: The Amazing Kreskin, Mentalist and 1970s Television Star, Dies at 89
description: His display of mysterious mind-reading powers on TV made him a pop culture phenomenon in the 1970s.
content: George J. Kresge, who as the entertainer the Amazing Kreskin used mentalist tricks to dazzle audiences as he rose to fame on late-night television in the 1970s, died on Tuesday in Wayne, N.J. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: The Grandpa Shoe Goes Hype
description: With a zesty collaboration arriving this week, the French shoemaker Mephisto is suddenly something it never dreamed of being before: cool.
content: Since Brian Procell first chanced upon Mephisto’s wide-set sneakers at his local suburban New Jersey mall in the 1990s, he has been smitten by the shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendy Doniger
title: Shadow of a Childless Woman: The Mythic Roots of Strauss’s ‘Frau’
description: What’s behind the strange emphasis on childlessness in “Die Frau ohne Schatten,” the Strauss-Hofmannsthal opera now at the Met? Look to the ancients.
content: Although the music of “Die Frau ohne Schatten” (“The Woman Without a Shadow”) is often transcendentally beautiful, it is among the least performed of the Richard Strauss and Hugo von Hofmannsthal operas at the Metropolitan Opera. Its relatively rare appearance on the Met stage is, I believe, in large part because of its weird, somewhat incomprehensible, and to some contemporary tastes offensive, libretto. The opera compounds the felony by being (at over four hours) the longest of all the Strauss-Hofmannsthal operas. Only “Der Rosenkavalier” comes close, but as “Rosenkavalier” is the best loved of all the pair’s operas, the length of “Frau” cannot be the only culprit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Technologists: Smarter-Than-Humans A.I. Will Likely Be Here by 2030
description: Most members of a DealBook Summit panel described immense benefits from artificial intelligence and saw its risks as manageable.
content: Powerful technologies have always been double-edged swords. That’s been true since fire; it could cook your food and keep you warm, but, out of control, burn down your hut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Ham
title: 120 Miles of Russian Forest Couldn’t Keep These Two Tigers Apart
description: Boris and Svetlaya were raised together as orphaned cubs, and then reintroduced to the wild separately. But Boris went on a trek that surprised the researchers who were monitoring him.
content: When Russian scientists released a pair of orphaned Amur tiger cubs into the wild in a remote corner of Russia’s far east in 2014, they were trying to save a species. While the tigers, sometimes called Siberian tigers and the world’s largest big cat, remain endangered, the scientists created something else: an unlikely love story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: 6 Engrossing Historical Novels to Keep the Chill Away
description: Curl up with these transporting reads.
content: These days, it’s hard to envision what Seiler’s translator, Tess Lewis, calls “the heady atmosphere of hope and disorientation” that followed the fall of the Berlin Wall. Luckily, Seiler’s STAR 111 (New York Review Books, 496 pp., paperback, $19.95) brings it all vividly back. An autobiographical picaresque, his novel reconstructs the exhilarating yet often terrifying experiences of individual East Germans in that brief period between the collapse of the Communist regime and reunification. Its central character, a 26-year-old aspiring poet, drifts through East Berlin’s anarchic underground squatter scene even as his parents abandon their home in Thuringia for a refugee camp in the West. All three find that freedom is a frustratingly vague concept, requiring constant improvisation. But what choice do they have, fleeing the ruins of an “abruptly obsolete, discontinued life”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman and Derek Arthur
title: The One Thing the U.S. Can Do to Help Syria Now
description: The editorial board writer Farah Stockman argues that ending the sanctions on Syria is the best way for America to help stabilize the country after the collapse of the Assad regime.
content: In this episode of “The Opinions,” Farah Stockman, a member of The Times’s editorial board, argues that letting U.S. sanctions against Syria expire, while not without risks, could go a long way to helping ordinary Syrians build a prosperous and stable nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Adam Lambert Is Finding the Fun, and the Fear, in ‘Cabaret’
description: Making his Broadway debut as the show’s Emcee, the singer is reveling in what he calls “a thinking piece of musical theater.”
content: Over at the Kit Kat Club, the change in “Cabaret” is apparent in the show’s first moments. The Emcee, as played by the singer-songwriter Adam Lambert, is nothing like the Emcee as played by the film star Eddie Redmayne, who opened the current Broadway revival last spring after it transferred from London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 550
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Dec. 12, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie Revisit ‘The Simple Life’
description: The celebutantes-turned-businesswomen are rebooting the show that provided a blueprint for the past 20 years of reality TV.
content: How would two troubled Los Angeles heiresses manage as members of the Bible Belt working class?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Elizabeth Williamson
title: Judge Rejects Sale of Infowars to The Onion
description: The Onion’s bid for the conspiracy website was supported by the families of victims of the Sandy Hook shooting and a nonprofit focused on ending gun violence.
content: A judge late Tuesday night said he would not approve the sale of Infowars, the website founded by the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, to the Chicago-based satirical publication The Onion, prolonging a messy tug of war between two high-profile suitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Man Who Leaped Over Bench to Attack Nevada Judge Gets Decades in Prison
description: A courtroom video recorded Deobra Redden as he ran up and attacked Judge Mary Kay Holthus at his sentencing hearing.
content: A man who was captured on video as he leaped over a judge’s bench and lunged at her in a Las Vegas courtroom earlier this year has been sentenced to decades in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: How Romania’s Fascist and Communist Pasts Haunt Its Politics
description: An ultranationalist politician’s surge shows how many people would rather forget the country’s fascist past, experts say.
content: It seemed a slam dunk: a proposal to rename an avenue running through the center of Romania’s capital that honored a World War II fascist functionary convicted of war crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: A.D.H.D. Diagnoses Are Surging Among Older Americans
description: Many say they are relieved to finally have an explanation after decades of struggle.
content: Over her life, Tanya Murphy had become accustomed to hiding her depression. In the Christian social circles in Georgia where she raised her three children, this was the rule — not the exception, she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: What Is Extradition? Can Fighting It Help the Midtown Shooting Suspect?
description: Under the Constitution, states are obliged to hand over other states’ fugitives if requested. But the process can be challenged in court. Here’s what to know.
content: Before New York can put Luigi Mangione, the suspect in the killing of a health insurance executive on a Manhattan street, on trial for murder, it has to get him back in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: The Torlonia Marbles Are Coming to Museums in Chicago, Texas and Montreal
description: For the first time, the ancient marbles are traveling out of Europe to the United States and Canada, for a prolonged stint.
content: Stashed away in a cavernous Roman deposit, hidden from the world for the better part of the last century, the Torlonia Collection — the largest collection of classical sculpture still in private hands — now appears to be continuing its jet-set itinerary that started in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Biden Administration Looks to Reinforce U.S.-China Ties Ahead of Trump’s Return
description: Senior Treasury officials are holding a final round of talks with a new round of economic volatility on the horizon.
content: The Biden administration is making a final push to reinforce the communication channels it established between the United States and China before the relationship between the world’s largest economies potentially faces fresh upheaval when President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: A Palestinian Winemaker Carries On
description: In the West Bank, Sari Khoury is trying to resurrect ancient traditions with grapes that reflect “the prehistory of modern winemaking.”
content: Sari Khoury, the proprietor of Philokalia in the West Bank, would prefer to speak of the craft of winemaking and the ancient winemaking history of Palestinians rather than of the precarious circumstances he must currently navigate simply to get his work done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Eduardo Medina
title: North Carolina G.O.P. Brushes Aside Democratic Governor to Expand Power
description: After cloaking a bill that strips key powers from Democrats as hurricane aid, the state’s Republican-controlled legislature overrode a veto from Gov. Roy Cooper, a Democrat, to pass it into law.
content: Republicans in North Carolina muscled through a sweeping expansion of their own power on Wednesday, overriding the Democratic governor’s veto of a bill that will give the G.O.P. increased control over elections, judicial appointments and whether its laws stand up in the courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: toboggan
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word toboggan has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 1 in the interactive “36 Hours in Zurich” by Noele Illien:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: New York Times and Tech Guild Reach Deal
description: The union, which represents some 600 tech workers at the publication, had been negotiating for a contract for more than two years. It will vote on ratifying the deal next week.
content: The Times Tech Guild, which represents tech workers at The New York Times, said on Wednesday that it had reached a tentative deal with The Times on a contract, after more than two years of bargaining and a weeklong strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Pistol Taken From Suspect Was a Fully Homemade Weapon, Officials Say
description: The ghost gun and suppressor found on the man accused of killing the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare were made with the help of a 3-D printer, authorities said.
content: The ghost gun that the authorities believe was used to kill UnitedHealthcare chief executive Brian Thompson last week in Manhattan was an exceedingly rare variety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Christina Djossa, Amy Pearl, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Diane Wong, Carole Sabouraud, Aman Sahota and Eli Tan
title: Dating Apps Suck. A.I. Clones Are Making Them Even Weirder.
description: Eli wasn’t finding a connection on the apps, so he did something drastic.
content: Fake profiles. Unresponsive texters. Boring conversations. An endless stream of dudes on boats holding the fish they’ve caught. Talk to single people using dating apps, and they are likely to tell you that the experience is awful, but that they have to be there. Dating apps are just how singles meet one another these days. But what if artificial intelligence could fix modern dating? The Times reporter Eli Tan explored that hypothesis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Collins Grills Hegseth but Remains Undecided on His Bid for Defense Secretary
description: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, said she questioned President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Pentagon on the misconduct allegations against him and other topics.
content: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, said she had privately questioned Pete Hegseth on both policy issues and the misconduct allegations against him but would not decide whether to back President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Pentagon until after a thorough vetting.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Two of You Are Sickening’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: For 22 years, Steve has been my tough, motorcycle-riding, dog-loving neighbor. He knows my life’s chaos — a broken heart, elder care, house repairs — and takes it upon himself to look out for me. This Christmas, he noticed my undecorated house. “You don’t have lights,” he declared matter-of-factly. Bypassing my protests about effort, waste and aesthetics, he admitted that he had already bought me some, then proceeded to string bright, mismatched bulbs across my porch. They’re not my style, but they’re unmistakably Steve: bold, unapologetic, full of heart. Sometimes love is letting someone’s unsolicited care light up your life. — Aimee Norman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: For Athletes, the Draw and the How of Branding
description: A task force at the DealBook Summit discussed how from college to pro sports, becoming a brand is a challenge.
content: If you’re Michael Jordan, the basketball superstar, you can be silent and still be a brand. But every other athlete needs to figure out how to position themselves if they want to move from great player to top recipient of sponsorship dollars and to one day being their own brand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: This Ohio-Hating Michigan Democrat Has Thoughts on Why Her Party Lost
description: Kristen McDonald Rivet won a tough House race in a heavily white, working-class area even as many Democrats in such places lost. In an interview, she warned against a “tone-deaf” economic message.
content: Democrats, rejected by many voters and headed for life in the minority in Washington, see few reasons for optimism these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Wayne
title: Women Need More Help to Rise in the Workplace
description: A DealBook Summit panel said a lack of helpful policies was hindering female advancement, while freezing eggs to postpone motherhood did not always work out.
content: While women appear to be doing better in many ways — two have even run for U.S. president as major party candidates — there has been limited progress in gaining leadership positions in business. That has to do with a lack of corporate and government policies to support women as they balance work life and home demands, concluded a task force of female business leaders, entrepreneurs and activists convened by The New York Times at the DealBook Summit on Dec. 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Private Insurers Must Now Cover Dyslexia Testing in New York
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul signed into law a first-in-the-nation bill requiring insurance companies to cover costs associated with dyslexia diagnoses.
content: A significant hurdle facing dyslexic children in New York was cleared on Wednesday, when Gov. Kathy Hochul signed a bill into law that requires private insurers to cover the costs of key diagnostic tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Why Was a Murder Suspect’s Instagram Taken Down, but Not His Goodreads?
description: Luigi Mangione’s social media accounts attracted swift attention after he was arrested in the killing of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive. When do companies scrub a digital trail?
content: Moments after the authorities announced that Luigi Mangione had been arrested in the killing of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive on Monday, people delved into his digital trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Tries Last-Ditch Move to Slash Nicotine Levels in Cigarettes
description: The agency is asking the White House, in the final days of the Biden era, to move ahead with plans to drastically reduce the addictive substance in traditional tobacco cigarettes.
content: In the final days of the Biden administration, the Food and Drug Administration is seeking White House approval to propose a drastic reduction in the amount of nicotine in cigarettes, a longstanding goal of public health experts that has faced stiff opposition from the powerful tobacco lobby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Britain Promised Clean Energy, but It Still Needs Oil
description: The government wants to rapidly replace oil and natural gas with renewable energy projects, but offshore wind and other alternatives are still in their early stages.
content: The government of Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain finds itself in a quandary. It came to power promising to lead a clean energy boom that it said would revive a stagnant economy and protect consumers from energy price surges that were driving up inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun and Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea’s Leader Holds Onto Power as the Net Closes In
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol shows no sign of stepping down, as investigators raided his office and more members of his own party turned against him.
content: Rival political parties on Wednesday wrangled over when and how President Yoon Suk Yeol should be removed from office, as the police and prosecutors investigating possible insurrection charges closed in on him a week after his ill-fated declaration of martial law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Could Cats Become a Carrier of Bird Flu?
description: A new study highlights the need for public health officials to ramp up bird flu surveillance in our feline companions.
content: Domestic cats could provide an unexpected new route for the bird flu virus H5N1 to evolve into a more dangerous form, according to a new study published on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Maria’ Review: A Diva in Decline
description: Angelina Jolie plays the opera star Maria Callas in a movie that can’t figure her out.
content: There is a moment, a little way into “Maria,” when you realize it shares a cinematic universe with another of the director Pablo Larraín’s recent films. This movie’s main character is the celebrated opera singer Maria Callas (Angelina Jolie). In a flashback rendered in monochrome, we see the night she met the absurdly wealthy business magnate Aristotle Onassis (Haluk Bilginer) — and he’s the future husband, we know, of Jackie Kennedy, who was the subject of Larraín’s 2016 film “Jackie.” Onassis, still married to his previous wife, claims he’s fallen in love with Callas through his opera glasses and invites her and her husband aboard his yacht; she seems lightly amused and a little irritated. “There’s a point where self-confidence becomes a kind of insanity,” she tells him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Liz Alderman
title: Houthi Attacks Turn Back the Clock for Shipping as Costs Pile Up
description: The transport route around the southern tip of Africa was once little used — but freighters are now forced to take it and are charging higher rates.
content: Before this year, Tobias Kammann, a German container ship captain, had only once sailed around the southern tip of Africa, and the lack of other vessels in the little-trafficked waters made him feel very much alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Why Trump Soured on F.B.I. Director Christopher Wray
description: By the time Donald J. Trump left the White House, he was eager to fire Mr. Wray, but he held back. His antipathy only heightened in the years after his presidency.
content: The announcement by Christopher A. Wray on Wednesday that he would step down as F.B.I. director ends a turbulent relationship in which President-elect Donald J. Trump repeatedly denounced a law enforcement agency he could not control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Nevins
title: The ‘Trump Dance’ Was Rebellious. Now It’s Just Everywhere.
description: Athletes did the awkward little shimmy to troll an imagined establishment. No one’s taking the bait.
content: Last month, in a game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, the San Francisco 49ers’ star defensive end, Nick Bosa, celebrated a routine sack with a cheerful and ungainly series of hip-swivels and fist-pumps, not unlike the movements of an automaton gaining sentience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Julian E. Barnes
title: Trump’s Record on Syria: Airstrikes and Troop Moves in a Land of ‘Sand and Death’
description: The president-elect faces hard choices about the country’s post-Assad future. His vows not to get involved might be hard to keep.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump will inherit a dangerous new Middle East crisis in Syria when he assumes office in January. But how he might approach a nation now controlled by rebels with terrorist roots is unclear, and may be decided by fierce competing arguments among advisers and foreign leaders in the months to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Bibi Files’ Review: The Case Against Netanyahu
description: This documentary about Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel looks at the corruption investigation and his enduring grip on the government.
content: “The Bibi Files” opens by promising to show viewers leaked videos from the police investigation of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel (ubiquitously known as Bibi), who is currently standing trial on corruption charges. The videos, a title card says, “are being shown for the first time in this film.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: The Pistachio Martini Is Beloved. And Baffling.
description: The creamy, pastel green drink is an enigma, but that doesn’t stop bartenders across the country from adding it to their menus.
content: At Caffé Vittoria in the North End of Boston, a drink arrives in a conical glass, a scoop of pistachio ice cream melting into the light green liquid. Served with a demitasse spoon, its taste falls somewhere between dessert and a boozy cocktail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt
title: Biden’s Top Aides Race to Middle East as Militias Wield Power in Syria
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken plans to hold meetings in Jordan and Turkey. Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, is visiting Israel.
content: President Biden’s two top national security officials left for the Middle East on Wednesday as the sudden fall of Bashar al-Assad, Syria’s longtime autocratic ruler, to militias has prompted a diplomatic scramble in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: ‘The Best Government Money Can Buy’
description: Under the influence of a coterie of tech boosters, it’s full speed ahead.
